title: Recent Research on Fasting and Calorie Restriction
editorial: This issue brings together major advances in fasting, calorie restriction, and metabolic adaptation — from long-term sustainability in humans to brain aging, cancer immunity, and epigenetic slowing of aging.

studies.title: Time-restricted eating may be easier to sustain than calorie counting
studies.summary: After a 12-week intervention, participants practicing time-restricted eating maintained their weight for up to six months, whereas those following calorie restriction returned to baseline within three months.
studies.commentary: Both strategies were equally accepted, but time-restricted eating was perceived as psychologically gentler, despite morning hunger and scheduling challenges.

studies.title: Calorie restriction reduces anxiety by calming brain inflammation
studies.summary: In obese mice, calorie restriction reduced anxiety-like behavior alongside major improvements in weight, glucose tolerance, and insulin sensitivity.
studies.commentary: The effects were linked to reduced neuroinflammation and microbiota-driven increases in short-chain fatty acid production.

studies.title: Hypoxic training amplifies lipid-lowering effects of calorie restriction
studies.summary: Combining calorie restriction with intermittent hypoxic training led to larger reductions in body fat, LDL cholesterol, and triglycerides than the same program under normal oxygen conditions.

studies.title: Intermittent fasting remains effective after disease onset in multiple sclerosis
studies.summary: When initiated after symptom onset in a mouse model of multiple sclerosis, intermittent fasting slowed disease progression and preserved myelin integrity.
studies.commentary: Benefits were linked to autophagy and cellular stress-response pathways involving the TRIB3–PERK axis.

studies.title: Lifelong calorie restriction preserves white matter in primate brains
studies.summary: Single-cell transcriptomics in rhesus monkeys showed that lifelong calorie restriction enhanced myelin maintenance, improved oligodendrocyte metabolism, and reduced microglial debris accumulation.

studies.title: Calorie restriction slows cancer growth by reprogramming immune cells
studies.summary: Rather than acting directly on tumors, calorie restriction altered neutrophil lipid metabolism, limiting lipid transfer to cancer cells and enhancing anti-tumour immunity.
studies.commentary: Low neutrophil HIF-1α expression was associated with better immunotherapy responses in lung cancer patients.

studies.title: Time-restricted feeding improves social behavior during aging
studies.summary: In aged mice, time-restricted feeding reduced brain inflammation, restored microglial rhythms, and improved social behavior.

studies.title: Weight loss without suppressing appetite
studies.summary: A novel peptide targeting GPR10 and NPFFR2 reduced body weight by increasing energy expenditure and fat oxidation, without lowering food intake.
studies.commentary: This contrasts with GLP-1–based approaches and points toward metabolism-focused obesity therapies.

studies.title: Fasting-mimicking diets reverse accelerated aging in multiple sclerosis
studies.summary: In people with multiple sclerosis, intermittent calorie restriction and ketogenic diets reduced metabolomic age, whereas daily calorie restriction did not.

studies.title: Six months of intermittent fasting reshapes human metabolism
studies.summary: A randomized clinical trial showed that six months of intermittent fasting improved body composition, lipid profiles, and induced coordinated changes in lipid, bile acid, and immune pathways.

studies.title: Hormone rhythms are essential for calorie restriction benefits
studies.summary: Calorie restriction increased the amplitude of glucocorticoid rhythms, which were required to activate fasting-adapted gene programs in the liver.
studies.commentary: These findings highlight circadian hormone signaling as a core component of calorie restriction biology.

studies.title: Short pre-surgery very-low-calorie diets are safe and effective
studies.summary: In patients awaiting colorectal cancer surgery, a short supervised very-low-calorie diet produced rapid weight loss and fewer surgical complications without adverse events.

studies.title: Calorie restriction reverses age-related lipid signatures in primates
studies.summary: Over 25 years of follow-up, long-term calorie restriction in rhesus monkeys opposed age-related rises in triglycerides and restored a more youthful lipid profile.

studies.title: Ketones are not required for most calorie restriction benefits
studies.summary: Mice unable to produce ketones still experienced most metabolic benefits of calorie restriction, including improved glucose control and liver autophagy.
studies.commentary: Ketone production declined with long-term adaptation, suggesting a transient signaling role.

studies.title: Long-term dietary restriction strongly improves insulin sensitivity
studies.summary: Lifelong dietary restriction markedly improved hepatic and peripheral insulin sensitivity in mice, with effects depending on diet composition and age.

studies.title: Alternate-day fasting protects against Parkinson-like pathology
studies.summary: In a Parkinson’s disease mouse model, alternate-day fasting preserved dopamine neurons, reduced α-synuclein accumulation, and lowered inflammation.
studies.commentary: Gut microbiota transfer reproduced much of the neuroprotective effect, highlighting the gut–brain axis.

studies.title: Exercise and calorie restriction converge on shared molecular signals
studies.summary: Combining muscle contraction with calorie restriction amplified irisin release in mice, exceeding the effects of either intervention alone.

studies.title: Succinate links intermittent fasting to brain and metabolic health
studies.summary: Intermittent fasting altered tissue distribution of succinate in obese mice, correlating with reduced anxiety and brain inflammation.
studies.commentary: Succinate supplementation reproduced many fasting-associated benefits.

studies.title: Diet matters more than age for mitochondrial protein damage
studies.summary: Calorie restriction, rather than aging itself, strongly reduced oxidative damage in heart mitochondria and reshaped brain oxidation patterns in rats.

studies.title: More restriction leads to slower epigenetic aging
studies.summary: Increasing levels of calorie restriction produced graded slowing of epigenetic aging in mice, with highly restricted old mice resembling much younger animals.
studies.commentary: Changes were closely linked to glucose and insulin regulation.

closing_note: As usual, feel free to comment, raise questions, or share this issue to help spread awareness about the science of fasting.
